column3: Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>--Dance. D-a-r-y-l, C-u-m-b-e-r, Dance, D-a-n-c-e.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>Velma Pollard, P-o-l-l-a-r-d.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Velma, tell me what it means to you as a poet, and as a West Indian poet, to be a part of this Furious Flower conference.</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>I am overwhelmed. I am flattered. I feel very special. I don't know why me. Chance is something else. If Joanne Gabbin had never met me, she would never have heard my name. If she</font>

<font color='navy'>didn't know you, she would never have met me. Because it's through you that she met me. If you had never come to Jamaica, you would never have met me. So it's chance, all the time.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Everything, I suppose.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>And I'm grateful.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Have you personally been affected by African American poets and poetry, in your own development as a poet?</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>I don't know that I can say my own development as a poet, but certainly as a person. And it's hard for me to think what has affected me as a poet. But it's much easier for me to</font>
<font color='navy'>understand what has affected me as a person. I came upon African American poetry, and literature generally, seriously in 1968.</font>

<font color='navy'>When I got a little work, in Harlem, in a storefront homework center, where I was supervising homework for children who didn't have parents who could do homework with them. I hired some undergraduates</font>
<font color='navy'>from Hunter College. And every afternoon, we supervised homework.</font>

<font color='navy'>This was my first time living in America. And I thought I need to know about this culture. I don't know. I knew hardly anything about it, except for the big names that everybody had read. And so I</font>
<font color='navy'>started to read. And I read and read and read, and a whole other world was opened up to me.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Wonderful. Could you tell me about other influences, early influences, family, place, home, school.</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>I think well, home, school, I think school. I think that I was impressed early in terms of poetry by some of the, I suppose some of the big names. I have to say that John Donne,</font>

<font color='navy'>although he was a religious man, to some extent, and an English man, and all the rest of it. But I think that very early in life I identified Donne as somebody who I related to.</font>

<font color='navy'>His passion, he was a man who was as passionate about a woman as he was about Christ. I mean, some of that poetry moved me as early in high school as I could remember. So that's where I remember</font>
<font color='navy'>first.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance

<font color='#008080'>You know, when I was at UWI, University of the West Indies in 1978, I always felt such a sense of awe to be in the presence of so many literary people. And I'd just like to know</font>
<font color='#008080'>what it meant to you to go to school there, to work there from all those years from the 1950s onward,</font>

<font color='#008080'>and to associate with notables at one time or another, such as Derek Walcott, Orlando Patterson, Jean D'Costa, Garth St. Omer, Sylvia Wynter, John Hearne, Slade Hopkinson, Mervyn Morris, Kamau</font>

<font color='#008080'>Brathwaite, Olive Senior, Pamela Mordecai, Lorna Goodison, Vic Reid, Louise Bennett, Ken Ramchand, Rex Nettleford, Eddie Baugh, Dennis Scott, Tony McNeill, Lorna Goodison, and of course your sister</font>
<font color='#008080'>Erna Brodber. What's it like to interact with--</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>The thing is that I am lucky that as you were calling those names, I was thinking-- I have never, I don't think of any of them as literary people, or artists.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>But you can't think of West Indian literature without thinking of--</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>But I don't think of West Indian literature. Those people are all people that I have known. I mean, I went to university with Eddie Baugh, Mervyn Morris, Garth St. Omer, the lot of</font>

<font color='navy'>them. The things I remember about them are unspeakable. They wouldn't want to remember the things that I remember about them. You know? I remember Garth St. Omer jumping over a fence to prevent me</font>
<font color='navy'>from doing something I would have been unhappy to have done. To go and spy on somebody. And he just stopped me and said you are not going.</font>

<font color='navy'>I don't remember that he has written novels, I remember that. You know, or I remember walking home from the union with Slade Hopkinson and those guys and just-- people mocking each other's accents</font>
<font color='navy'>because we're all from different islands. Things like that that are not at all literary. So because I knew all these people before they became important, it--</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Well in later years tell me about interactions. I know you've collaborated,</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>Yeah, well the interaction at this-- now when I came back onto the campus, and all my little friends were now important people, this was awe. I remember going to an eight o'clock class</font>

<font color='navy'>to hear Mervyn Morris lecture and losing my one gold earring. And I said now, why was I even at that lecture at eight in the morning, who invited me? But I didn't know Mervyn as a lecturer or</font>
<font color='navy'>anything.</font>
Or going to hear Eddie Baugh. Talk about Brathwaite's-- there's this poem called Rights [of Passage]. Eddie Baugh gave a phenomenal lecture on Rights. And he read from that poem. You

<font color='navy'>know, Eddie Baugh's voice is the best thing in the Caribbean. Reading Kamau Brathwaite. That was like 19-- I came back in 1975. So that may have been '75 or '76. And I recognized that the little</font>
<font color='navy'>people that I had known, had grown. They had become mountains.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Do you remember where you--?</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>I said-- hmm?</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>I'm sorry, do you remember where you were when you found out that Derek was a Nobel Laureate?</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>I must have heard about it before I saw it on the-- I can't remember where I heard. I know that I was at the TV to watch him receive the prize. And I really was overwhelmed. Well, the</font>
first thing I did when I heard that he got it, I phoned a young American scholar who I know who had told me that he would never get it because of The Boston Sun.
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Oh, yes.</font>
Velma Pollard
And I said, people know that it's not his private life that they're giving him the prize for. In any case, most West Indians don't believe that story in that way. Because people

<font color='navy'>in the Caribbean are accustomed to saying things to people that they don't really mean all the time. I read Walcott's poetry, and I see some of it and I read the way that people analyze it, and the</font>
<font color='navy'>high sounding words they say about it.</font>
<font color='navy'>And I say-- I'll give you one quick example.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Yes, please.</font>
Velma Pollard
This is one of my favorite Walcott poems. It is, I think it's called The Light of the World. A lot of people have written a lot about it, it's supposed to be a poem from which

<font color='navy'>another life came or something. All kinds of things have been said about it. But the lines where he says, "O beauty, you are the light of the world!" Oh, they have gone to Italy, they have gone to</font>
<font color='navy'>everywhere, to assess it.</font>

<font color='navy'>And I know that Caribbean men say things like this to women all the time. Oh, lady, Moses must have been sleeping when one like you left heaven. Who knows if Moses was even in heaven? But that kind of</font>

<font color='navy'>thing is said, so "O beauty, you are the light of the world!" And I say, you know, they've said everything about it but they have not said this is a man as they would say in Ghana souring a woman.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance

<font color='#008080'>Yes, yes. You know, Velma, when you told me about that, it reminded me of what I know once about you're giving a book to a publisher, and his offering to have somebody check the</font>
<font color='#008080'>Creole for you.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>Yes!</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Talk a little bit about responses from so called, 'First World' publishers and critics and so forth to either your own word or other--</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>Well, in this case, the person they were asking to check my Creole-- unfortunately, I had heard her give a lecture, and her English was not so hot. So I wrote back and I told them that</font>
<font color='navy'>what I did for a living was teach people about Creole. Had they known that they may not have suggested this.</font>

<font color='navy'>And I said, if you don't want to publish the book, that's fine. But I'm not going to change anything. And since I had tested it and found somebody who does not speak the Creole who was a Canadian</font>

<font color='navy'>visitor who didn't have a problem with it. I can write an explanation about the use of the Creole. And so I wrote the afterword, and that satisfied them. Generally speaking, I think it has been a bit</font>
<font color='navy'>of a battle that was won before I started writing seriously, was half won.</font>

<font color='navy'>The other thing, and here I'm quoting Olive Senior to a certain extent, she was saying once-- and I don't doubt that she remembers saying it-- that she's glad that she was already a professional in</font>

<font color='navy'>her own right before she became well known as a writer. And I think I can't use the well known for myself, but I can say that I am also glad that I had sort of made my name professionally before, so</font>
<font color='navy'>that I could stand up and say, if you don't want to publish my book, well, that's fine, but this is the situation.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>And to some degree, I guess the generation of Vic Reid and Sam Selvon and those people, yeah, paved the way. Exactly.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>They paved the way for us. This is why I say we benefited from what they did. Yes.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance

<font color='#008080'>Velma, let's talk a little bit about your creative process. I remember once you told me you started out writing everything down on a yellow pad. Is that still the way you work?</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>I thought this morning as I was sitting in front of you writing in my yellow pad, that maybe you know that a poem is coming, yes. I do not travel without the yellow pad. Sometimes it's</font>

<font color='navy'>not yellow, sometimes it's white because sometimes I can't find a yellow pad, but it's mostly yellow-- and a pencil. I don't know why but I really-- I think that what I get from that is the immediacy.</font>
<font color='navy'>When I get a thought like what I was writing this morning, it is immediate.</font>

<font color='navy'>So when I go back to it, I'm responding to something that was, what Houston Baker just called the... impulse? I like that term. If you wait to write at the computer, or at your desk, you are going to</font>
<font color='navy'>lose that. First thing, I don't have the kind of memory that would ever take things with me into when I get comfortable.</font>

<font color='navy'>So when it was not the yellow pad, it was a note paper at the kitchen table when I had less time for myself. And I was always busy. And even now if I go to sleep, I always have a pencil and a page. I</font>
<font color='navy'>fold the computer sheet the used sheets over. And I always have that and a pencil on my bed. I may write something to buy in the supermarket tomorrow, or I may write a line.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>But when you say, when you had less time for yourself are you speaking of when you had a family?</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>Bringing up children working on, you know, doing more things than I should have to do. Yes, that's--</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Would you share with us one of your favorite poems and tell us a little something about its history and its composition?</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>Well, I'm not sure that this is my favorite poem, but I think it's other people's, because it is my most anthologized poem. And it did come out in the first six or so poems that I had</font>
published. So it's an old poem. Pam Mordecai put together, Pam Mordecai and Mervyn Morris put together Jamaica Woman in 1980 before any of the women in here had their own collections out yet,
and this was included. It's called Fly.

<font color='navy'>"ef a ketch im/ a mash im/ ef a ketch im/ a mash im/ ef a catch im...// Will you walk into my parlour/ Said the spider to the fly/ It's the prettiest snugliest parlour/ that ever you did spy... And I/</font>

<font color='navy'>the fly/ inspecting your web/ this skein now then that/ put my microscope eye/ through its intricate weave/ saw valleys of cloud/ blue and serene/ saw acres of grass/ sheltered and green./ Ephemeral</font>
<font color='navy'>and light/ I rested my life/ and dazzled/ I watched/ you wove me inside/ and dazzled/ I slept/ my chrysalis sleep...//</font>

<font color='navy'>*** I woke up inside/ no more dazzled and green./ Awake and alert/ unfolding my wings/ I stretched/ But your skeins/ not delicate now/ resistant and strong/ they wove me inside/ I am trapped/ I can't</font>
<font color='navy'>move/ I can't butterfly/ fly//</font>
<font color='navy'>And you/ perched outside/ your eyes large and clear/ you see acres of green/ you see valleys of cloud/ you can move/ you can fly.../</font>

<font color='navy'>Now I look through the web/ I look into the void/ I see numberless flies/ training microscope eyes/ through intricate weave/ ANANSI I cry/ ANANSI-SI-SI I hear/ the sky is too vast/ how it scatters my</font>

<font color='navy'>cry/ the sky is too clear/ it hides my despair/ they can't hear/ they can't see/ with their microscope eye...// ef a ketch im/ a mash im/ ef a ketch im/ a mash im// A ketch im... im... im//"</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Is that an autobiographical poem?</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>The thing is, it might be, but I really do not know. Because I think I may have started out by thinking 'ef a ketch im/ a mash im/ ef a ketch im/ a mash im', which is the way the train</font>
<font color='navy'>goes up the hill in Jamaica, 'ef a ketch im/ a mash im/ ef a ketch im/ a mash im'. And our trains have to-- used to, we have no trains now-- used to go up very steep hills.</font>

<font color='navy'>I think it started with a notion that when we were saying it in elementary school, we were not really listening to the words, that it is a cruel refrain. In other words, if anybody's on the train</font>
<font color='navy'>line, when the train is coming, the person is going to die. So, 'ef a ketch im/ a mash im'. I think that's where it started that kind of realization.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>But no thought of the woman entrapped by the rails.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>And then, I was about to say,</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Oh, I'm sorry.</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>it moves to the woman entrapped. And not just me, but all other women, I mean, running for that trap rushing to get to the point where you want to go to the cinema but you have to go</font>

<font color='navy'>home to cook. Women rush to get to it. And then they realize. Too late, I suppose. It is a very cynical poem but I didn't think it was cynical when I was writing it. But the more I read it, the more</font>
<font color='navy'>it sounds cynical.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Is it simply that you've moved on to another period so that you aren't quite the feminist?</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>As trapped?</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Well, quite the feminist that I think I hear there.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>Well, and people accuse me of that. But I don't know if feminist is just realist. Perhaps reality is what they call feminism, you know, just describing the truth.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Okay. And talk a little bit about Anansi, and using that--</font>
Velma Pollard
Anansi. Well, you know, Anansi is the patron saint of insects in a sense. Anansi, and I've used Anansi a lot. I have a collection called Anansesɛm which is a word for Anansi

<font color='navy'>stories, a word from Twi in Ghana. Anansi came to us from Twi, from the Akan tradition, he is both a spider and a god. For some reason, in Jamaica, he took on a trickster personality.</font>

<font color='navy'>But, and a trickster personality that I consider to have been much maligned. Anansi gets the better of people, but gets the better of people by finding their Achilles heel. I mean, snake was so proud</font>
<font color='navy'>of his length and power and what have you. Anansi humbled him by just discovering, you know, what really was at the heart of his notions about himself, and using it.</font>

<font color='navy'>So we have all this blame for Anansi. Anansi tricks people and all the rest of it, but Anansi only tricks people who can be tricked. Anansi, I cry. I'm warning them, Look, don't come into this net.</font>
<font color='navy'>But only if you can listen, will you hear. So that's, that's Anansi.</font>

<font color='navy'>They always talk about Caribbean people, and the Anansi-ism. I'm sure you've heard of it up here, where we come and in no time we have a house and whatever. And it's all because of our tricks. But I</font>
<font color='navy'>think Anansi is about taking opportunity when it offers itself, and just looking around and making sure that you see it.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>And much industry.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And much industry. Anansi, I think, is part of a migrant personality, it need not be a West Indian coming to America or going to England, it could be any migrant going anywhere. And that same person</font>

<font color='#008080'>at home is quite laid back. People from here come to the Caribbean just to comment on how laid back we are. And then they meet us up here and say how industrious we are. It's the same people.</font>
<font color='#008080'>Different situation.</font>
<font color='#008080'>And you know, our Brer Rabbit is brother to Anansi.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>Yeah, right. Yes, I know.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>The very same tales as a matter of fact, of African origin obviously, are told here with Brer Rabbit.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>Maybe a different folk tradition within Africa.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance

<font color='#008080'>Exactly. Exactly. Velma, your latest collection of poetry seems so much more reflective about the concerns of aging, and even dying. And I suppose that is a kind of natural</font>
<font color='#008080'>progression as we age and experience the deaths of our parents and friends and what have you.</font>

<font color='#008080'>But one in particular, I want to ask you about though you may say something generally about the subject matter and your interest in the kind of subject matter that we see in your poems more recently.</font>
But one poem, We Are Our Grandmother's concludes, 'I know that I am grand'. Talk a little bit about what you're saying there.
Velma Pollard
Gran. Well, that is really harking back to the short story that is not so short about Gran, which is about, which is perhaps my only autobiographical piece about my grandmother.

<font color='navy'>And this is a woman who really, I have always had a great respect for. When her husband died she had seven children: one was nine, the oldest, and the youngest was nine months.</font>

<font color='navy'>And she-- now, she was not poverty-stricken, I have to admit. There was land, there was a mill and copper, which is what they used to make sugar. But all of that stuff her husband was in charge of and</font>

<font color='navy'>he just died quite suddenly. And I remember her at the mill and copper, giving orders to men so much taller and bigger than she was. And just getting out there at six o'clock every morning and doing</font>
<font color='navy'>what had to be done and,</font>

<font color='navy'>She's established herself as a baker so she was baking, she was selling sugar where people would come to the boiling house to but by the sugar in these pans, sort of, and making sure there was enough</font>

<font color='navy'>money to put all the children through school. So whenever I see myself doing something and people say, how do you manage that? I know that I'm not doing much, I'm doing a quarter of what she did. But</font>

<font color='navy'>in a sense I am Gran. And I'm not sure which bit of Alice Walker's work I had read. Why I dedicated it to her. Oh, she said, 'We are all grandmothers'. Yes, yes, that's it. That's how that came--</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>You once said that Gran is an excuse to "big up" a strong female symbol of Jamaican peasantocracy. How important do you see that still, in Jamaican society?</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>I see its lack, still. And I think that a lot of the people who have gone astray now have not had access to this kind of person, nor respect for this kind of person. Everybody wants to</font>

<font color='navy'>get rich very quickly. My grandmother had to do lots of things so that my mother could have a profession, so that she could want me to have a profession. Everybody wants to be well off, or to get</font>
<font color='navy'>where I am, and that's not being that well off, but comfortable. Everybody wants to get comfortable in one generation.</font>

<font color='navy'>People long ago sacrificed, knowing that the next generation would benefit. Nobody is willing to sacrifice now. That's why we have in Jamaica, young women leaving their babies at home to go to dances.</font>
<font color='navy'>Do you know how many children die by fire in my country, because their mothers went to a dance? Went to a dance, and left the children there.</font>

<font color='navy'>So it's a kind of-- I think that we need to get back to saying, not that we want them to be downtrodden or anything, but we just want people to take responsibility and to know that there were people</font>
<font color='navy'>who take responsibility.</font>

<font color='navy'>And the word "peasantocracy", I like it. Because an academic, a social scientist on the campus, spoke tongue in cheek of my sister and I said, ha, they're not poor people my dear, those are from the</font>

<font color='navy'>peasantocray. And what he meant is that we grew up in the country and people think, 'where did they even learn to read books?' But there were books, and there was knife and fork and doilies and all</font>
<font color='navy'>these little things that you expect in homes of people who have money. So that -ocracy, peasantocracy, he labels for people like us who behave as if we...</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Came from the aristocracy?</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>But we don't really. They are from right down there, the peasanto--. So it is a put down, but a nice put down.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>Well, speaking of your sister, we certainly have to get to that famous writer as well. And I'd love for you to share my favorite story, about...</font>
Velma Pollard
Oh, you mean how Jane and Louisa came to be published.
Daryl Cumber Dance
Exactly, Jane and Louisa, of course, is one of the classics of modern Carribean literature, yes.
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>Of Carribean literature. Well, my sister is a social scientist.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Can I interrupt? Could you say your sister's full name? [Inaudible] want to hear it.</font>
Velma Pollard
<font color='navy'>I'll say it. Yes. Well Erna Brodber is my sister. B-r-o-d-b-e-r is my maiden name and her name. She's a social-- a historian, a social scientist, and what have you.</font>

<font color='navy'>And she had been well known in that she's written things like abandonment of children, yards in the City of Kingston. And that's how she made her name. And then she came up with this volume, which she</font>
<font color='navy'>showed me in 1975. She had been dissatisfied with what her social science students had to read. There were no Caribbean models, only things out of America and England.</font>

<font color='navy'>So she decided to write something about growing up in Jamaica so that her students could relate to it. What happened to it is that her students never got to it. The literary people appropriated it,</font>

<font color='navy'>and it has become a Carribean classic. But she, when I reached home in 1975, she had this manuscript and I read it and I said, This is magnificent what's going on here? So I made 12 copies and sent it</font>
<font color='navy'>out to some friends and had them comment on it. And Gordon Rohlehr, who is a quite famous Carribean critic was as excited as I was.</font>

<font color='navy'>And he said, "Well, you know, this just has to come out". He has a very slow delivery, but anyway. I was going to London for some other reason. And I took it with me on his advice to John La Rose, who</font>
<font color='navy'>publishes New Beacon, who grabbed it and published it. And that's the tale.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance
<font color='#008080'>And the rest is history.</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>The rest is history. Since then, La Rose, New Beacon has published two other novels of hers and what have you. She has continued writing and she's writing-- she also has continued</font>

<font color='navy'>writing academic things. She has had four academic manuscripts already in one year. Two are out already, and two are in press. And she has a novel coming. She's a very prolific writer, so.</font>
Daryl Cumber Dance

<font color='#008080'>Tell me about the two of you as writers. Do you often give feedback regarding manuscripts to each other? Or does she not dare that you get your hands on another one of hers before</font>
<font color='#008080'>she decides what to do with it?</font>
Velma Pollard

<font color='navy'>No. The thing is, the answer is yes and no, because it never works quite like that. Because we have so many other things to deal with, family matters, all kinds of down to earth things.</font>

<font color='navy'>But I mentioned in the foreword to one of her books, which she intended to send for you, but Ivan came, so she couldn't get from-- to me. So I didn't see her before I came, so. But she says you will</font>
<font color='navy'>get a package with all of them. She'll just wait till the four come out. Four [inaudible], yes.</font>

<font color='navy'>But she decided, well, one of my brothers and I decided that she should not be so poor, when she's so bright. So we thought a series of lectures and this became lectures and a meal. You go to Woodside</font>

<font color='navy'>on a Sunday, you pay a certain amount of money, and you'll get a lecture and a meal. Well, not many people were interested in this kind of lecture because it was really about Jamaican history and</font>
<font color='navy'>sociology, but written in such a way that the man in the street could understand it.</font>

<font color='navy'>Was about 10 lectures, and she really worked very hard, preparing them and reading all this stuff. First few, maybe she had 10 people and then maybe five and then soon it was just my brother and I.</font>

<font color='navy'>So, anyway, what she got out of it was she put this set of lectures together. Something about I can't remember the whole title, it ends in 'Consciousness', though. And one book is those 12 lectures</font>
<font color='navy'>put together. So in that way, I have benefited. I mean, I just sit and listen to her in awe.</font>

<font color='navy'>I don't have to read all that stuff, because she has read it. And I just read what she has produced for the man in the street, and so. Or, well, let me see how I benefit from it. I, last year I was an</font>
<font color='navy'>online consultant, I think, for a literature course at Fairleigh Dickinson University.</font>

<font color='navy'>So when they asked me a question that I didn't understand, you're online so you don't have to answer immediately. I would telephone her and get the absolute accurate answer. Something about, say Kamau</font>
